abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Second Santiago Water and Sewerage
            Project in Chile. The project had three objectives: a) to
            support the first phase of a plan to alleviate the sewage
            disposal and reuse problems with a view to reducing the
            incidence of typhoid fever and other enteric diseases; b) to
            upgrade potable water quality and increase available water
            quantity by improving operation and maintenance and reducing
            water losses in the water distribution system; and c) to
            strengthen the management and cost control system of the
            Empresa Metropolitana de Obras Sanitarias (EMOS). Overall,
            Bank performance was satisfactory. EMOS is considered one of
            the more efficient water utilities in Latin America. Overall
            its performance has been very satisfactory, especially after
            overcoming initial delays. The relationship between the Bank
            and the Borrower was generally cordial. The main lessons to
            be learned from this project are: a) Significant
            improvements in the performance of the sector and its
            utilities require a well-functioning regulatory and
            institutional framework; b) To avoid unnecessary delays in
            project implementation, it is essential to have detailed
            designs for a given percentage of the project subcomponents
            before project effectiveness; c) In the case of an
            experienced and efficient utility such as EMOS, a project
            designed from the outset to finance a time slice of its
            investment program versus a project approach would have
            precluded the adjustments needed to accommodate the shift in
            priority as it emerged during project implementation.
            Overall, Bank performance was satisfactory. EMOS is
            considered one of the more efficient water utilities in
            Latin America. Overall its performance has been very
            satisfactory, especially after overcoming initial delays.
            The relationship between the Bank and the Borrower was
            generally cordial.
